instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1398: What is A1398? A1398 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2015, Mid 2012, Early 2013, Late 2013, Mid 2014 with EMC 2909, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00138, 820-00163, 820-00426, 820-3332, 820-3662, 820-3787..
definitions.820-00138: What is 820-00138? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-00163: What is 820-00163? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.LCDBKLT_EN_L: What is LCDBKLT_EN_L? This signal enables the backlight when it is low.  _L means the signal asserts itself when the voltage is low. This signal needs to be low to enable backlight. .
definitions.D7701: What is D7701? diode in the backlight circuit sitting between the BKL_SW pin of the LED driver and backlight output. Very common for via between this and BKL_FB for feedback to blow, causing no boost. Measure continuity between pin 2 of this diode and feedback pin of LED driver if backlight output is PPBUS_G3H with no boost.
definitions.BKLT_EN_R: What is BKLT_EN_R? This signal enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. The “_R” suffix means that the signal is asserted when it is high, as in 3.3v, which is the opposite of the “_L”  suffix.
definitions.BKLT_SD: What is BKLT_SD? BKLT_SD is a pin of the LED driver that goes to the voltage divider that feeds the gate of the transistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H and the backlight circuit. The LED driver will short this pin to ground when backlight circuit is ready to turn on. Prerequisites are 1) it is told to turn on via enable signal, the screen has communicated with the LED driver 2) current sensing circuit is working 3) does not detect an over-current situation such as the backlight power rail being shorted to ground.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message:
Hi,

I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A that only boots sometimes.  On visual inspection i notice that the coil near the display lvds connector is broken.
I can't find that coil on the boardview neither on schematics. However, i found one coil just on that position (L2920) on the boardview of the <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A.

My problem is that i don't have any other scrap board like this one, and don't know were to find that coil to replace it. Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message:
L2920 is the same on both boards.
That shouldn't cause problems, as it is for thunderbolt, which you don't use, I suppose.

Boots only sometimes means doesn't even turn on?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message:
Hi,
Sometimes it turns on, and give image. Other times it turns on, has green light, fan spin, but no image (not shure if it has USB activity because now it is booting).

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message:
So the machine ALWAYS turn on, but not always gets image?
You must be sure if board boots then.
Boot is not the same with turn on.

If you don't get image, or at least USB activity, no reason to search for backlight.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message:
Hi,
You're correct. The machine turns on, but not always has image.
I don't get image, but i have USB activity.
I have 12.5V on F7700

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message:
If you get always USB activity, but no image, then is something related with LCD data lines.
Try first known good LCD assembly.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message: I've tried with a known good lcd with the same result. No image, but with USB activity

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message:
When the problem appears, do you get voltage at pins 28-30 of J8300?
Clean the contacts, ckeck L/<CHIP>U8300</CHIP>.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message:
Hi,
I have 5V on pins 28-30, and already cleaned L/<CHIP>U8300</CHIP>, but still no image.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message:
5V always present there, means the panel is detected (<SIGNAL>LCD_HPD</SIGNAL> is high).
In such case, check all FL8300-03 coils and adiacent capacitors.
You may need to change J8300.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message:
I can't see no problem on the coils or on the caps, besides the fact that on diode mode all 4 pins on the coils are showing OL (0V).
Shall i replace J8300?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message: The mentioned coils must be checked between their pins, not to ground (diode mode).

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message:
Hi,

I measure  continuity on the coils, and all of them seams to be ok. However, I believe that I should have a burst of voltage (around 2.5V) on the FL8300, but i have none.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message:
If you tested knwon good (compatible) screen, then change LCD connector.
Compare diode mode readings on data lines with good board.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message:
Hi,
Thanks. It was the LCD connector. After replacement, now it works all the time.
A strange thing was that I mesure on diode mode (on other board, and before and after replacement), and both readings were very close.
Thanks!

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message:
Hi again.

After all, the connector replacement doesn't solved the problem, or it has a new problem. It came back again with no backlight. I get 12.5V on F7700, and have image on external monitor. I can see an image when point a lamp on the back of the lcd.

I have 11.9V on <SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_EN_L</SIGNAL> (<RESISTOR>R7701</RESISTOR>)

Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message:
Check diode mode to ground at both pins of <DIODE>D7701</DIODE>; w/ and w/o screen connected.

Is <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN_R</SIGNAL> present?
Clean LCD connector pins.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message:
Diode on  <DIODE>D7701</DIODE>:
With LCD:
1= 0.430V
2 = 0.640V

W/O LCD:
1= 0.430V
2 = 0.640V

<SIGNAL>BKLT_EN_R</SIGNAL>  = 3.3V

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message: Now post the voltage on both pins of <DIODE>D7701</DIODE>; with screen connected.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message: 5V on both pins, with lcd connected

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message:
Really strange.
If <SIGNAL>BKLT_SD</SIGNAL> is high, you should NOT have voltage at all at <DIODE>D7701</DIODE>.
Did you measure correctly?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message: Well, i think i wasn't. My boardview on this board isen't good for sure. The <DIODE>D7701</DIODE> isn't there. I was mesuaring on <DIODE>D7720</DIODE>. Do you have a good bordview?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message:
Real boardview not available.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> has some differencies.

In your board, <DIODE>D7701</DIODE> is placed between coil and filter caps.
<DIODE>D7720</DIODE> is for keyboard backlight.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message:
OK.
On that one ( <DIODE>D7701</DIODE> ) I have 10V on pin 1 and 45V on pin2.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message:
45V is a bit higher than normal backlight voltage.
I think 39V is correct level.
This means you have a problem with video cable, or broken LED strip inside LCD panel.
You may also have bad contacts inside J8300.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message:
Tks.
I have tried with two different known good lcd, and the J8300 is a new one (replaced again yesterday)

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message: Check which is the correct backlight voltage on working machine.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message: Don't have any other 1398. Is there any other way to be sure?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message:
The Apple logo lights on the top cover?
If not,
"you have a problem with video cable, or broken LED strip inside LCD panel.
You may also have bad contacts inside J8300."

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message:
HI,
I've replaced J8300 again, and now it seams to be always working. AIt should be as you said (bad contact).
TKS!

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message:
Did you check backlight voltage on the working moment?
Note it, as it will help you in the future diagnostics.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message:
Hi,

Yes I note it and it is 45.7V. I Don't know if this is the right voltage for this model, but in this particularly mac (is the only one that I have here), that is the backlight voltage, on a working state. On future one, I'll compare it.

Thanks.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message:
Hi,
After all, It doesn't work again. Something very strange is happening:
Once again, after i replaced the J8300 the backlight works for a day or two, but than it stops working.I gues that is someting related with the temperature applied (just guessing).
Any idea of what mite be causing this behaver?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message:
What is backlight voltage now.
If higher than normal, there is a problem with the connection with LEDs strip.
If voltage is correct, then you have a problem with the image.
If lower, or missing voltage, then be sure to get image first.
